review_title: Good place to work! Same problems as most academic institutions.
pros: Wake Forest offers really generous PTO. It also does a good job of keeping staff abreast of big strategic decisions. Also, I love the access to LinkedIn learning. There are really a lot of perks (Wellness Coaching, good mental healthcare, free basketball games, etc.).
cons: Academia tends to underinvest in management training. People get positions of management by being good at things other than management (research, teaching, fundraising). It also seems like a pretty culturally white place (I say this as a white person), pretty class-conscious.

pros: Coworkers are great! Sense of purpose here (students) Job stability Beautiful campus Nice benefit package
cons: Virtually no career progression Leadership overlooks staff (focus is on faculty) Low morale Expected to work beyond job description for years because “other duties as assigned” 2% is the standard yearly increase. According to salary.com, staff I know are in the bottom 30%. Very bureaucratic and slow since the pandemic.

pros: Beautiful campus, hardworking student body, majority of faculty and staff have worked at wake long-term
cons: Old school residential campus mentality

pros: Good people and good environment

review_title: Excellent Employer and Champion of Healthcare Equality, Equity, Inclusion and Diversity
pros: The Executive Director Dr. Allison Matthews is an outstanding leader and champion at building partnerships with Faith-based organizations and the LBGTQ communities to address the needs of vulnerable populations such as rural communities in Appalachia, African Americans and LGBTQ individuals. These groups, particularly in the South, often experience a higher number of cases of HIV/AIDS with access to fewer support and prevention resources.
cons: Normal growing pains of an upstart business.

pros: Wake has a personal touch in working with students and our constituents. Offices and equipment are beautiful as are the campus grounds. Professionals here are respected and supported, with many people growing and promoting in place or finding good work in other areas on campus. Lots of opportunity to be engaged outside of your direct work. Discounts to games. Benefits are really good. Free food abounds at events.
cons: No transparency in salaries: makes it difficult to recruit and retain talent. Salaries are lower in comparison to the local market and salary compression is common. Communication from campus leadership could be better.

pros: Benefits rock, pto amazing, 403b gets better with time
cons: Manager was a jerk and his secretary was a female dog

pros: Education and training were good

review_title: Great benefits, great mission, beautiful setting, but could be better

pros: A very strong academic institution.

review_title: Not a bad place to work

cons: I felt a bit siloed into my academic department, but that's probably just COVID

review_title: Great place to work with good pay and management.
pros:
Good pay for a lifeguard. It's not as good as a city pool but there's a reason they make more. City pools you will be contently saving people and dealing with more customer medical issues than an athletic pool like the one at Reynolds Gymnasium.
Flexible schedule. You can block off any time you want to work or don't want to work with complete freedom. 
Good Communication. I do not know if the person I worked under is still there but there was great communication. Expectations were clear and if you had a problem you could contact them easily.
There are opportunities to get into instructing swim lessons which is great money.
cons:
They hired an excess of employees. If you wanted more hours you had to aggressively take shifts on the trade board. if you aren't checking religiously you might miss the opportunities for extra shifts. 
During the summer the pool isn't open straight throughout the day. The pool closes a couple times a day for an hour or two. So even if you want to work an 8 hour shift most days that doesn't exist.

review_title: Excellent school, friendly/helpful staff, balanced work environment
pros: Large IT staff for a school of this size. Work hours are from 830am-5pm and there does not seem to be a lot of people working overtime.  Benefits are decent and reasonably priced; PTO is combined vacation and sick.  Work-Life balance is fine.  There is room for growth - people have been 'promoted' to higher level positions.  Turnover, in general, appears to be low.
cons: The IT dept (known as IS) is off campus which makes daily interaction with the rest of the campus difficult, except for the service/help desk - they are in the library.   Academic departments use distributed IT staff (non-IS staff members)  which work directly with faculty leaving IS at a somewhat disadvantage - but communication is improving.  Leadership within IS has been here a long time.  A new CIO is pending.

review_title: Make a difference. Learn a ton. Enjoy the benefits
pros: Wake Forest is a great place to exercise your creativity to make a difference in the lives of students, faculty, and staff (depending on your role). I enjoyed being able to come up with programs, new initiatives to strengthen the culture and hone my skills. I felt supported by my team most times and there were endless opportunities for professional development and training. The benefits are fantastic - new facilities and wellbeing initiative encourage self-care. You can also live well with the compensation/salary offered.
cons: Performance management and career growth within the organization needs improvement. Once in a role, you can remained locked in if the department doesn't have the funds for promotion. The annual review process could be better and feel futile at times since there are no real incentives other than personal improvement. Very relationship oriented community is good, so it's important to set your personal/professional boundaries.

review_title: Great place, can be political and sometimes overworked for what you're paid
pros:
--Opportunities (can network with lots of different people)
--Good pay
--Respected company (Wake Forest carries a lot of weight)
--Rewarding (doing great things that help the department)
--Relaxed office culture 
--Generally great people in the office (nice and want to get the job done)
cons:
--Political (definitely favoritism, some cattiness and lots of gossip)
--Poor management (systems are unnecessarily complicated and could easily be simplified)
--No boundaries as far as job requirements 
...Some of the professors request jobs that they should honestly do themselves...sometimes they even request jobs that violate copyright laws, like asking to photocopy a whole book--very awkward to tell them why you can't do it
...Basically was asked to do the responsibilities of another job in addition to my normal job

review_title: Dedicated, thoughtful leadership that takes an interest in developing employees and building a positive work environment
job_title: Wake Forest Fellow in Winston-Salem, NC
pros: Access to senior leadership provided an unbelievable learning environment. Coworkers are smart, driven, and accomplished. Work has meaning. Input is valued.
cons: Program structure is not uniform across all Fellowship positions. Sharing insights across departments could be helpful to standardizing effectiveness of the program.

review_title: Being Resident Adviser is a mixed bag
pros:
Solid housing subsidy and compensation, even if it isn't as good as it used to be. 
For those really engaged by the idea of mentorship, working with first-years can be enjoyable. 
Upperclassmen position require relatively little work.
cons:
RA apacement can be less than ideal, if not arbitrary. 
You will find yourself and your friends constantly complaining about ResLife. 
Some nights on duty can be truly stressful and time-consuming. Consider yourself warned. 
Some RAs clearly follow rules/care about the job more than others.

review_title: Good sense of community; very low pay
pros:
Great sense of community
A sincere commitment to diversity and inclusion (although much work has to be done on actually achieving this in practice)
cons: Politics can stunt great initiatives; oftentimes initiatives and programs are changed without proper evaluation or trying them a second year to measure year-to-year outcomes; very very low pay and a concerted effort to keep paying under market value for positions; expectation to work over-time in spite of low pay; much of pay issues stem from a very dysfunctional HR (the list of grievances for the HR team is too long to list here).

review_title: Wait and decide before you start working here
job_title: Post Doctoral Research Fellow in Winston-Salem, NC
pros: Top notch researchers and projects happen here. Researchers are No.1 in the world. Projects are fascinating and interesting to work in.
cons:
You are worked as if you are a slave. You handle 4-5 people's job all by yourself. 
International students and employees like me have to face a tough time with immigration process.

pros: Great city, good weather. Career enhancement courses offered by the employer. Great co-workers and students. Good benefits. Funding available for travel and personal enhancement. Beautiful, peaceful campus. Great IT support. Lots of teaching and research resources available.
cons: Very low pay. Bureaucratic, slow-moving HR structure. A lot of back and forth between different people in management positions before any problem is solved. People in charge of visiting international students and scholars affairs are a joke, they don't even answer emails. Not many opportunities to grow: merit evaluation rules are not clear for either merit-based salary increase or promotion.

review_title: A great school with knowledgeable professors.
pros: The workload was reasonable for most professors. As long as you are willing to put the time into the classes, you will do very well. The professors all have an open door policy and will help you whenever you want. The teaching assistantship is a relatively easy job and helping the students can be rewarding.
cons: There are certain professors that you do not want to TA for because they give you as much work as they can.

pros: Wake Forest has been a wonderful learning environment for me for the past two and half years.  The professors and the administration all care about the students.
cons: The parking passes are tremendously expensive and if you do not arrive early you will likely not be able to find a parking spot.

job_title: Teaching Assistant Professor in Winston-Salem, NC
pros: A really great university that has a great student - professor ratio. They have treated me really well here with raises each year, good benefits, and great colleagues. The campus is gorgeous too.
cons: It is hard to think of any cons. There has been a lot of construction going on and it has at times been disruptive. Perhaps they could have scheduled more of it over the summer when there are far fewer people on campus.

review_title: WFU is like working for a small community
pros: Benefits are wonderful. A great teamwork environment. Working with some really talented, and nice people. Having the opportunity to work with others on campus with different projects.
cons: Leadership, work environment, micro managed, holding employee back from sharing good ideas, blame shifting, giving vague instructions, and last but not least not recognizing each individual and giving them the praise they so deserve!

pros: Great co-workers. Prestigious reputation (looks good on a resume). There's a lot of investment in student services.
cons: Very low morale and high turnover. Goals are unreachable, but you're punished for not reaching them. Micromanagement. Constant changes to strategies without giving them a chance to work. No idea how some people get promoted while other great employees don't. School talks about ethics in business, but treats employees unethically.

review_title: Is this a good place to work?  Depends on who you work for.
pros: amazing PTO (25 wks), good benefits, good reputation in the community/well respected and good on the resume.  depending on the job you do, it can be rewarding/something you'ver very passionate about.
cons: poor management - usually faculty members who have been given grants and not neccessarily any management skills; compensation is far below private sector; working with difficult faculty members.  Little room for growth.

review_title: Okay but communication could be better
pros: Friendly staff and coworkers. The pay is great and there are great benefits the university offers. Manager was great also.
cons: Lack of communication, upper management is disorganized and only care about what they feel is important. So be prepared for the law school to put your concerns on the back burner. The students are their number one priority.

pros: Top notch school with growing programs.  Great opportunity to support students in college environment.  Small, intimate campus that promotes peer collaborations across units.
cons: The university can be very traditional.  Institution maintains an attitude of "that's the way things have always been done' rather than exploring new avenues to enhance the overall program.

review_title: record turnover and not good leadership. no structure or process.
pros: benefits are supposed to make up for low pay but don't. students are working adults. Free parking.
cons: leadership, support, low pay, professors are catered to with paid chauffers and full offices but they are never there and never speak to staff. Charlotte employees have nothing.

review_title: Be cautious of Wake Forest University but overall a good place to work
pros: Fellow Employees are great to work with; Most work hard and have a great work ethic; Great atmosphere to work in.
cons: Pay scale is poor but it is a not-for-profit;  Advancement is very short coming and rare; Hours of work vary a lot.

pros: Relaxed, stress-free environment, nice campus, benefits
cons: Leadership unable to make decisions or take action.  Pay.  I was promoted twice with no increase in pay.  As a manager, I was making less than my subordinates.   Not a very challenging environment or one where you get recognized or rewarded for your hard work.  They reward you for doing nothing.

pros: WFU was a great employer.  I was a 9 month employee, so my schedule was the absolute best.  I feel that it was my best job to date.
cons: I had to relocate because of my husbands job.  The only complaint that I would have would be is that there was no option to extend your pay over a 12 month period rather than 9 months so when I was not working for the other 3 months of the year I wasn’t getting paid.

review_title: Business school has no idea how to run a business
pros: allow for flexible work schedule
cons: no feedback at all after 4 years.  Very top-down management style.  Very behind the times in terms of how to engage and retain employees.  leadership is virtually all men.

review_title: Faculty and Staff are both welcoming and extremely supportive. I've enjoyed my time here.
pros: Laid back department with great resources and connections. Great work environment! There are many opportunities to collaborate across the university or with other labs at the medical school campus.
cons: Expectations aren't always clear. The current chemistry department needs severe remodeling. Teaching labs can be a big headache because of poor communication with previous lab coordinators and overall disorganization of information.

pros: Nice campus and small community size. You can get enough care from your advisor. You can have undistracted time to focus on what interests you.
cons: Sometimes life is boring in a small town. And when it comes to job hunting, it's less competitive to other large technical institutes.

pros: The last time I was there (which was before Wake Forest changed store management over to Follett), it was pretty laid-back. Great people, no stress. I also got to drive a golf-cart, which was pretty nice.
cons: You're not going to really advance that much. Also, it was 7.25/hour, but hey, a monkey could do my job.

pros: The college campus is a beautiful setting to work in. The benefits are very good. And the paid time off is more than generous.
cons: A homogenous workplace that caters to Wake Forest graduates. Speaks about diversity and inclusion but is not diverse or inclusive at all. There is racism and favoritism in the workplace and senior management is unaware or doesn't care that it is so pervasive.

review_title: Research Assistants treated well, paid little
job_title: Graduate Student Research Assistant in Winston-Salem, NC
pros: Supportive community, beautiful campus, great connections to be made.  The work was challenging, I was treated with respect, and my insights were valued.
cons: The pay for research assistants is quite low.  If my only goal were to make money, I could have earned more doing pretty much anything else.

pros: Beautiful place to work, great paid time off, good work/life balance, nice people.
cons: Very low pay and very secretive about the process for promotion or asking for a raise. Women do not advance as quickly as men. Once you're hired in at a specific rate, they will do everything they can to keep you there. The review process is meaningless, especially if you're an exceptional worker because you will not be rewarded for outstanding work.

review_title: PhD candidate on Bowman Grey campus
pros: Work life balance is great, graduate stipend is better than average, great faculty, cross departmental collaboration, excellent location ,well rounded students
cons: No major connections to industry, Winston Salem is not for singles, poor affiliation with undergraduate campus, some PIs can be difficult to work with

pros: Its great working in Higher Ed. Its' fun to watch you people evolve into adults.
cons: There is an elitist attitude on campus. Almost no racial diversity..95% of the staff are white and some don't make you feel welcome. I've never felt like I was part of the Wake Forest Family . There are no minorities in leadership roles and promotions are often given without the position being posted.

pros: Extremely intelligent directors and coworkers. The work getting done is greater than the sum of the individuals conducting it.
cons: Very strong personalities throughout the departments. If someone is not used to working with very meticulous individuals with very stringent expectations, then this job could become stressful.

job_title: Information Systems (Former Employee) in Winston-Salem, NC
pros: Great vacation, retirement benefits, dependent tuition reimbursement, main campus is beautiful, coworkers are great, little to no travel, holidays off
cons: Horrible leadership. No room for growth. Leadership is belittling to employees. You are not allowed to speak freely. Employees are made to feel unimportant. The list goes on and on. It all boils down to horrible leadership within Information Systems.

review_title: Center for Injury Biomechanics is extremely research-driven while encouraging continued education.
job_title: Graduate Student Research Assistant in Winston-Salem, NC
pros: The best part of this job is working with world-class faculty and students in an environment that encourages growth, leadership, learning, publishing, and attending conferences.
cons: The worst part of this job is perhaps the balance between work and home life that is asked of students, but with enough passion for your work and research, even this is hardly something to be noticed.

pros: good pay and nice people run the place for the most part. It's fairly relaxed and low-stress most of the time.
cons: Sometimes feels like it's being left behind and that its only strategic goal is to increase its position on the us news rankings

pros: They had a very flexible schedule that fit well with my status as a full-time student. I also had a very friendly work environment with helpful and friendly bosses.
cons: The location of my work-study was fairly far away from the main campus. However this was not a huge con.

job_title: PhD Graduate Student in Winston-Salem, NC
pros:
Sparing amount of graduate students allow to matriculate into the program.
Umbrella program for PhD allows students that are unsure of their route to explore different options.
cons:
Low availability of mentors.
As always mentors require an extensive amount of time to be spent in the laboratory.

review_title: Wake Forest has a great reputation and needs to value employees who helped build it.
pros: Excellent reputation as a quality institution. Former strong sense of community.
cons: Lack of communication to existing employees and faculty. Focus on new employees and their growth.

pros: I worked as a student with Wake Forest University Athletics. It was an amazing first job as a student! The hours were flexible around my school schedule and the environment was welcoming and positive.
cons: There really aren't any cons. Working with the payroll site was somewhat difficult but once you worked with it a few times it was pretty easy.

review_title: Excellent first year in the work force.
pros: Fellow works with upper level management on special projects at their discretion. The access and career development is unique to this program.
cons: The salary is low but Winston-Salem is a fairly affordable city. Winston Salem does not have all the activities that a larger city like Raleigh or Charlotte have.

job_title: Coordinator of Intramural Sports/Club Sports in Winston-Salem, NC
pros: Great work environment. Benefits [Insurance (medical, dental, vision), PTO, etc.) Work-life balance is phenomenal.
cons: The salary for this position is not competitive and is at the very bottom of the range in the industry. There is little to no room for bonuses, promotions, etc. Those seeking career advancements will have to seek the promotion on another campus.

review_title: Excellent leadership that truly knows how to motivate
pros: Great place to work. Fun and positive environment. In my particular role, I was able to interact with everyone from bottom to top of the hierarchy. Supervisors are helpful and find ways to motivate you and keep you engaged.
cons: Not really any cons. It is a great university.

review_title: Jobs ok pretty good benifits and pay starting off and perks like Paid time off extra paid holidays if you want to work
job_title: First Shift Custodian in Winston-Salem, NC
pros: Jobs ok pretty good benifits and pay starting off and perks like Paid time off extra paid holidays if you want to work
cons: Working everyday could use more money add elevators in every building

pros: There have been some changes recently, but coming into a beautiful campus every day definitely is great. There is a great employee support system with HR who are very receptive to any questions.
cons: Even though it IS primarily a university, having more lunch options on campus during the summer would be excellent.

job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in Winston-Salem, NC
pros: Great campus, and plenty of events you can join in even as a grad student. Housing and cost of living overall in the area is cheap.
cons:
Pay is low (for graduate students, not for staff/faculty), but you're going to find that at most places.
The cost of a parking pass was ridiculous.

pros: Amazing opportunities to connect with the students and the community through university events
cons: Does not appreciate staff employees

job_title: Writing Center Tutor in Winston-Salem, NC
pros:
--Excellent tutoring/teaching experience
--Faculty support
--Diverse group of students, from freshmen to grads
--Good hours, especially for busy students
--Fun
--Would recommend this job for students who would want teaching experience
cons: --The pay is hourly/stipend--this job is intended for graduate/undergraduate students rather than full-time job seekers--just keep that in mind

job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in Winston-Salem, NC
pros: This is a great place. Quite environment, nice people. Not a lot pressure. The place to be if you want a real life.
cons: This is a little town, not a lot of career opportunities. If you are ambitious, this might not be the place for you.

pros: Definitely a good place to work that offers a lot of freedom. Every one here is willing to talk. Coming from the North East, I never had a problem with the culture. Super accepting.
cons: There's nothing really wrong. I wish the pay were higher

pros: Wake is definitely a place that takes into consideration the work-life balance of its employees.
cons: Not enough development for those that find themselves in managerial or supervisory roles.

review_title: Benefits less than great, but good work environment
pros: Collaborative work environment. Great people to work with.
cons: Old boy networking still reigns.

job_title: VRC Executive Assistant in Winston-Salem, NC
pros: Great supervisors, friendly atmosphere, flexible hours. The staff are incredible to work with and I never had a bad day at the VRC.
cons: None! I had no problems here. They're a great group of people that are sociable and fun to work with.

job_title: Assistant Director of Admissions in Winston-Salem, NC
pros:
-Great benefits, especially the generous paid time off. 
-Beautiful surroundings
-Smart people, young people (who keep you young)
-Great reputation
-Lots of paid holidays
-Flexible work environment
cons:
-Low pay
-Women seem to advance at a slower pace
-Parking challenges
-Young people (enough said)
-Unrealistic goals
-Convoluted appraisal process

pros: Lot of good folks at wake forest professors are smart and helpful. Having a degree from here looks pretty fresh also.
cons: Pretty small school here at Wake. The small class sizes are nice but sometimes can get old after a little while

review_title: WFU has a high standard for students and faculty. The emphasis on service is especially strong.
pros: Wonderful students who bring amazing experiences and motivation to the classroom.
cons: WFU is getting 'too big for its britches' in some ways. Work/life family balance is nearly impossible.

pros:
Close to where you live
Easily work around class schedule
cons:
Yelled at by other students
Training is very rushed and shallow
Very low hourly pay
Constantly asked to work additional hours due to lack of personnel

pros: Excellent Benefits and Family atmosphere.
cons: Overextended and overworked administration sometimes negatively affects the effectiveness of those lower on the totem pole. Expected to constantly turn out a product or bring in money.

pros: Great connections, everyone is eager to help you network if you're willing to take the initiative.
cons: Wouldn't recommend for someone who needs constant oversight; type of position only well-suited for those who can self-manage.

pros: Outstanding business program, best classes include Capitalism, Strategy, and Organizational Behavior Classes. Glad to have attended.
cons: Lack of diversity, food is bad, parking on campus is nearly impossible, administration is overbearing and ineffective.

pros: benefits great, Another Dept. would be the best area to work
cons: Custodian area tremendous turn-over in help, Potential to rise above for other positions not available/rather considered.

pros: Good Experience and Great Students that teach you valuable lessons about scholarship and theory.
cons: Low pay for a lot of critical reviews, and grading. You play the professor on occasion.

job_title: Employer Relations Specialist in Winston-Salem, NC
pros: Stimulating academic environment in perfect sized city.  Great team of people with whom to work
cons: Like most jobs in academia, the pay is not very competitive and processes are sometimes slow, unlike for-profit organizations.

pros: It was just a research assistant position, so it was flexible hours and interesting work.
cons: It was just a research assistant position while I was a student, so I had no advancement opportunities obviously.

pros: The work environment is overall acceptable.
cons: The professor and upper management are rude and look down on staff employees.

job_title: Ticket Sales Consultant in Winston-Salem, NC
pros: Within the athletic department, Wake Forest really makes an effort on including everyone.  We are all part of a team.
cons: Staff is divided across a few buildings

pros: Great vacation and sick leave, flexible schedule
cons: The specific school I worked in was not good. Unrealistic expectations of staff. Very poor moral.

job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in Winston-Salem, NC
pros: Everyone takes a personal approach and is very friendly. This is a great environment.
cons: Sometimes the corporate body of the university seems to forget about basic needs like parking.

review_title: WFU Theater and Dance Box Office
pros: The box office had a fun and collaborative energy.
cons: Selling tickets over the phone was sometimes difficult because the customer could not visualize the theater.

pros: Academic community, laid back environment
cons: The town, low salaries for professors, the student body

job_title: Camp Counselor in Las Vegas, NV
pros: You get a very good salary for minimal effort.
cons: You are constantly being judged by Tony himself overseeing you.

pros: A employer with 14000 people. A lot of job opportunities, particularly for healthcare related professional.
cons: For research position, it is grant dependent. Pressure is high

pros: Generous paid time off, sick leaves, parental care leave and 403b plan
cons: None if your salary is not grant dependent.

job_title: Associate Project Manager in Winston-Salem, NC
pros: Flexibility in position, great coworkers and convenient locale
cons: Lack of promotions, no leadership and absent upper management participation.

review_title: Hours of a lawyer, pay of a janitor
pros: Good people and fun atmosphere
cons: very long hours for a lousy paycheck

review_title: Good work environment, safe and collaborative
job_title: Research Assistant Professor in Winston-Salem, NC
pros: Benefits, job security, interactions with faculty and staff are positive
cons: Pay, limited upward mobility, limited colaboration between departments

review_title: Great job if you are willing to work nights
job_title: Graduate Teaching Assistant in Fairfax, VA
pros: Respectful boss, good pay, great career development resources
cons: Late hours, not a lot of upward mobility

pros:
Salary benefits  are competitive.
small campus with manageable size of school
cons: too much management/ politics/ donations oriented/ corporate style system

review_title: Long term goals at Wake Forest University
pros: Great Benefits and Professional Development depending on the department.
cons: Leadership depending on the department can make or break you.

pros: Academic atmosphere. Tons of collaboration, good people.
cons: Indecisive IT leadership.  Unfocused IT approach to the new world of technology.

pros: Sense of community and pride in the university, decent opportunity for advancement
cons: Compensation may not be as competitive as other universities

job_title: MA Management Student in Winston-Salem, NC
pros: Devoted teachers, great institution, beautiful campus, stellar degree
cons: Panders to bottom 30% of program at times, could be more rigorous

job_title: Graduate Teaching Assistant in Winston-Salem, NC
pros: As a graduate student, I love the math and stats department
cons: I do not like the university as whole

pros: Exceptional PTO, beautiful campus, a close knit sense of community
cons: Can't get anyone in HR to call me back to answer questions or issues.

pros: Nice atmosphere, friendliness of staff and good benefits.
cons: With the current construction it can be difficult to navigate to work.

pros: People here are friendly, and students are working hard
cons: there is a little bit lack of structure sometime

pros: Understanding coworkers, supervisor, great place to grow in ministry.
cons: Unusual hours, and long retreats that require prescheduling

review_title: Wonderful experience at the call center
pros: Quality on-campus compensation, accommodating for students

review_title: Wake Forest Athletic Communications Student Worker
job_title: Student Worker In Athletic Communications in Winston-Salem, NC
pros: Fun work, mixing athletics with work
cons: Sometimes inconvenient hours, like 8-12 on a Saturday night.

job_title: Student Athletic Events Management in Winston-Salem, NC
pros: treated very fairly, surrounded by a great group of people
cons: long hours but they are transparent with that

review_title: Loved it! Small campus, great location
job_title: Graduate Student Assistant in Winston-Salem, NC
pros: Tight knit community, lots of local resources, caring faculty.
cons: Expensive parking, grad student fees

pros: flexible hours, lots professional development workshops
cons: nothing - it was a great part time job!

job_title: University Postdoctoral Fellow in Winston-Salem, NC
pros: Beautiful campus, great people, good benefits
cons: Relatively low pay for most employees and not much room for upward mobility

pros: One of the best places to attend school
cons: A little expensive in comparison to other schools

pros: Nice place to work with friendly atmosphere.
cons: Low pay for a good university like this.

pros: Relaxed and positive work environment

job_title: Administrative Assistant in High Point, NC

pros: Fun structured environment. Easy learning job responsibilities. Linear progressions.
cons: Some work monotonous, but to be expected.
